stem: The gastroenterology nurse is reviewing the multi-viral panel for a client with deteriorating liver function. Based on the documentation in the Multi-Viral Co-infection Log, match the Hepatitis marker to its correct clinical implication.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient: (Mr. Gupta, 48 years old). Known chronic Hepatitis B carrier for 10 years. Presents with sudden onset of liver failure (Fulminant). 
Initial labs: ALT 1,200 (Extremely elevated), PT/INR 3.2 (Elevated), Jaundice 4+.

tabs.title: Multi-Viral Co-infection Log
tabs.content:
MarkerResultImplication
HBsAg (Hep B Antigen)Positive (+)Ongoing Hep B infection
Anti-HDV (Hep D Antibody)Positive (+)Superinfection present
Anti-HCV (Hep C Antibody)Negative (-)No Hep C

tabs.title: Clinical Status
tabs.content: Client is confused (Encephalopathy). Liver is small and firm. Bilirubin is 12.0 mg/dL.

columns.text: Requires a co-existing or previous HBV infection to replicate
Provides indirect protection against future HDV infection
High risk when HBV and HDV occur simultaneously (Superinfection)

rationale.correct: Hepatitis D (r1) is a 'defective' virus that CANNOT replicate without Hepatitis B (c1). Therefore, vaccinating against Hep B (r3) is the primary way to prevent Hep D (c2). When these two occur together (Superinfection), the risk of fulminant (sudden) liver failure (r4) is extremely high (c3).
clinicalPearls: No Hep B = No Hep D.
Hep D is common in the Mediterranean, Middle East, and among IV drug users.
Superinfection (D on top of an existing B) is much more dangerous than co-infection (Getting both at once).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking there is a separate vaccine for Hepatitis D.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that the ONLY way to prevent D is to prevent B. There is no stand-alone D vaccine.
